answer_html: \(\int_0^x\frac{t}{1-t^8}\textrm{d}t \approx\int_0^x\left(t+t^9+t^{17}\right)\textrm{d}t=\frac{x^2}{2}+\frac{x^{10}}{10}+\frac{x^{18}}{18}\) produces the first three non-zero terms of the desired integral.
answer_latex: $\int_0^x\frac{t}{1-t^8}\textrm{d}t \approx\int_0^x\left(t+t^9+t^{17}\right)\textrm{d}t=\frac{x^2}{2}+\frac{x^{10}}{10}+\frac{x^{18}}{18}$ produces the first three non-zero terms of the desired integral.
hints_html:
What is the Maclaurin series expansion of

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{1-x}\end{aligned}\]

?

This should look very familiar to the problem at hand.
hints_raw:
What is the Maclaurin series expansion of

:<math> \frac{1}{1-x}</math>?

This should look very familiar to the problem at hand.
question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
Recall the following Maclaurin series expansion

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{1-x} = 1 + x + x^{2} + x^{3} + ... = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}x^{n}\end{aligned}\]

Now plugging in \(x = t^{8}\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{1-t^{8}} = 1 + t^{8} + t^{16} + t^{24} + ... = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}t^{8n}\end{aligned}\]

and then multiplying by \(t\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{t}{1-t^{8}} = t + t^{9} + t^{17} + t^{25} + ... = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}t^{8n+1}\end{aligned}\]

Hence, the first three nonzero terms are

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle t, t^{9}, t^{17}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^x\frac{t}{1-t^8}\textrm{d}t &\approx\int_0^x\left(t+t^9+t^{17}\right)\textrm{d}t\\ &=\left.\left(\frac{t^2}{2}+\frac{t^{10}}{10}+\frac{t^{18}}{18}\right)\right|_0^x\\ &=\frac{x^2}{2}+\frac{x^{10}}{10}+\frac{x^{18}}{18}\end{aligned}\]

produces the first three non-zero terms of the desired integral.
sols_raw:
Recall the following Maclaurin series expansion

:<math> 
\frac{1}{1-x} = 1 + x + x^{2} + x^{3} + ... = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}x^{n}
</math>

Now plugging in <math>x = t^{8} </math> gives

:<math> 
\frac{1}{1-t^{8}} = 1 + t^{8} + t^{16} + t^{24} + ... = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}t^{8n}
</math>

and then multiplying by <math>t </math> gives

:<math> 
\frac{t}{1-t^{8}} = t + t^{9} + t^{17} + t^{25} + ... = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}t^{8n+1}
</math>

Hence, the first three nonzero terms are 

:<math> 
 \displaystyle t, t^{9}, t^{17}.
</math>

Therefore,

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int_0^x\frac{t}{1-t^8}\textrm{d}t &\approx\int_0^x\left(t+t^9+t^{17}\right)\textrm{d}t\\
&=\left.\left(\frac{t^2}{2}+\frac{t^{10}}{10}+\frac{t^{18}}{18}\right)\right|_0^x\\
&=\frac{x^2}{2}+\frac{x^{10}}{10}+\frac{x^{18}}{18}
\end{align}
</math>

produces the first three non-zero terms of the desired integral.
statement_html:
Find the first three nonzero terms in the power-series representation in powers of \(x\) (i.e. the Maclaurin series) for

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^x \frac{t}{1-t^8}\,dt.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Find the first three nonzero terms in the power-series representation in powers of <math>x</math> (i.e. the Maclaurin series) for
:<math> \int_0^x \frac{t}{1-t^8}\,dt.</math>
